questions.text: TCA cycle is called amphibolic cycle because

options.label: A
options.text: It is both exothermic and endothermic

options.label: B
options.text: TCA cycle intermediates used in both amino acid and purine synthesis

options.label: C
options.text: It can occur in both forward and backward directions

questions.correct_answer: A. It is both exothermic and endothermic

questions.text: Which tricarboxylic acid first formed in TCA cycle
Which of the following is unaltered final product of TCA cycle
Which of the following is carrier of TCA cycle?
Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate + CoA-SH. Which is true for this reaction
Which of the following is a correct sequential order of TCA cycle once acetyl CoA enter into TCA cycle
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Oxaloacetate, α-ketoglutarate, citrate: This order is incorrect because oxaloacetate is not the first compound that enters the TCA cycle. The first compound to combine with acetyl-CoA is oxaloacetate, forming citrate. So, this order incorrectly places oxaloacetate at the beginning, even though it is the last compound to regenerate in the cycle.
  • • (C) Citrate, oxaloacetate, α-ketoglutarate: This order is incorrect because after the formation of citrate, the TCA cycle progresses to the formation of α-ketoglutarate before oxaloacetate is eventually regenerated. So, oxaloacetate should not come immediately after citrate.
  • • (D) α-ketoglutarate, oxaloacetate, citrate: This option is incorrect because α-ketoglutarate is formed later in the cycle, after citrate undergoes transformations. Therefore, this sequence does not follow the correct order of reactions in the TCA cycle.

questions.text: How many dehydrogenase take part in TCA cycle
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) 2: This option is incorrect because there are more than two dehydrogenases in the TCA cycle. The cycle involves four key dehydrogenase enzymes, each catalyzing specific oxidation steps.
  • • (B) 3: This option is also incorrect because, as explained, there are four dehydrogenases, not just three. The three listed enzymes would leave out one crucial step.
  • • (D) 5: This option is incorrect as well because there are no five dehydrogenases in the TCA cycle. There are only four, as detailed earlier.

questions.text: All the enzymes of TCA cycle are present in mitochondrial matrix except
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Malate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is located in the mitochondrial matrix, where it catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate, reducing NAD + to NADH in the process. Since it is located in the matrix, this option is incorrect.
  • • (C) α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is also located in the mitochondrial matrix, where it converts α-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA, reducing NAD + to NADH and releasing CO 2 . Since it is within the matrix, this option is also incorrect.
  • • (D) Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Isocitrate dehydrogenase is found in the mitochondrial matrix and catalyzes the conversion of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, reducing NAD + to NADH and releasing CO 2 . Therefore, this option is incorrect as well.

questions.text: CO 2 releasing reaction in TCA cycle is catalyzed by which enzyme
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Citrate synthase: Citrate synthase catalyzes the condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate to form citrate. This reaction does not involve the release of CO 2 . Therefore, this option is incorrect.
  • • (C) Fumarase: Fumarase catalyzes the hydration of fumarate to form malate, but no CO 2 is released in this reaction. It is simply a hydration reaction, not a decarboxylation. Hence, this option is incorrect.
  • • (D) Succinate dehydrogenase: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate, and during this reaction, FAD is reduced to FADH2. There is no release of CO 2 in this reaction, making this option incorrect as well.

questions.text: Two carbons leaves from TCA cycle in form of CO 2 are derived from
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Fumarate: Fumarate is a product of the TCA cycle, formed by the oxidation of succinate. It does not directly contribute carbon atoms that are released as CO 2 in the cycle. Therefore, this option is incorrect.
  • • (C) Oxaloacetate: Oxaloacetate is involved in the formation of citrate when it combines with acetyl CoA, but it does not directly provide the carbon atoms that are released as CO 2 . Instead, it helps regenerate at the end of the TCA cycle, making it an intermediate rather than a source of carbon for CO 2 release. This makes this option incorrect.
  • • (D) Succinyl CoA: Succinyl-CoA is an intermediate in the TCA cycle, formed after the decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate. While succinyl-CoA is involved in reactions that produce ATP or GTP, it does not contribute the carbon atoms that are released as CO 2 in the cycle. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: NADH produced by which enzymes in TCA cycle
Which of the following TCA cycle substrate for the only physiological irreversible reaction
All of the following vitamin requires for proper functioning of TCA cycle except
Which of the following inhibitor bind to CoA and condense with oxaloacetate to inhibit TCA cycle
Arsenite inhibit which enzyme of TCA cycle
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Succinate dehydrogenase: Succinate dehydrogenase is involved in converting succinate to fumarate in the TCA cycle. While arsenite is toxic and can affect some enzymes, it primarily targets enzymes like α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase rather than succinate dehydrogenase. Therefore, this enzyme is not inhibited by arsenite.
  • • (C) Aconitase: Aconitase catalyzes the isomerization of citrate to isocitrate in the TCA cycle. While aconitase can be inhibited by other substances like fluoroacetate, arsenite does not inhibit it directly. Aconitase is more susceptible to iron depletion than to arsenite inhibition.
  • • (D) Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Isocitrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate in the TCA cycle. Arsenite does not inhibit this enzyme. While other factors may inhibit isocitrate dehydrogenase, arsenite does not directly target this enzyme in the TCA cycle.

questions.text: All of the following reactions of TCA cycle are source of energy except
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Isocitrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, producing NADH and CO 2 in the process. NADH is a high-energy molecule that is later used in the electron transport chain to produce ATP. Therefore, this reaction is a source of energy.
  • • (C) Succinate dehydrogenase: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate, generating FADH 2 in the process. FADH 2 is another high-energy molecule that participates in the electron transport chain to generate ATP. This is an energy-producing reaction.
  • • (D) Succinate thiokinase: Succinate thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate, producing GTP (or ATP, depending on the cell type) in the process. This is a direct source of energy because GTP can be used in cellular processes or converted to ATP.

questions.text: FAD is a cofactor for the which of the following enzymes
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Malate dehydrogenase: Malate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate. However, it uses NAD + as a cofactor, not FAD. NAD + is reduced to NADH in this reaction, which is later used to generate ATP in the electron transport chain.
  • • (B) α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: The α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes the decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA, and it requires NAD + (not FAD) as a cofactor. In this reaction, NAD + is reduced to NADH, not FADH 2 .
  • • (C) Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Isocitrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, and it uses NAD + as a cofactor, which is reduced to NADH during the reaction. This enzyme does not use FAD.

questions.text: 3 NADH and 1 FADH 2 per TCA cycle, produce how many ATPs
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) 15: This is not correct. The total ATP produced from 3 NADH and 1 FADH 2 is 11 ATP, not 15. The discrepancy likely comes from a miscalculation or assumption that all ATP yields are maximized in every step, which is not typically the case.
  • • (B) 12: This is also incorrect. As discussed, the combination of 3 NADH and 1 FADH 2 yields a total of 11 ATP (not 12). The ATP yield calculation should be based on standard cellular conditions and yields.
  • • (D) 6: This is not correct either. 3 NADH and 1 FADH 2 give more than 6 ATP. The 9 ATP calculated in option C is more accurate.

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation reactions in TCA cycle is catalyzed by
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) α-keto glutarate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes an oxidative decarboxylation reaction and produces NADH and CO 2 , but it does not directly catalyze a substrate-level phosphorylation reaction. Therefore, it is not responsible for substrate-level phosphorylation in the TCA cycle.
  • • (B) Succinate dehydrogenase: Succinate dehydrogenase is involved in the conversion of succinate to fumarate, and it produces FADH 2 but does not participate in substrate-level phosphorylation. Instead, it is part of the electron transport chain as it is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • • (D) Malate dehydrogenase: Malate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate, producing NADH, but it does not generate ATP or GTP via substrate-level phosphorylation. This enzyme is part of the oxidative processes of the TCA cycle, not a substrate-level phosphorylation reaction.

questions.text: TCA cycle is not regulated by
Glucogenic amino acid produce all of the following intermediates of TCA cycle except
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Fumarate: Glucogenic amino acids, such as phenylalanine and tyrosine, can be converted into fumarate. This intermediate is part of the TCA cycle and can eventually contribute to glucose production via gluconeogenesis.
  • • (B) Succinyl-CoA: A number of glucogenic amino acids, such as valine, methionine, and threonine, are converted into succinyl-CoA, which is an intermediate of the TCA cycle. Succinyl-CoA can also contribute to glucose synthesis via the process of gluconeogenesis.
  • • (C) α-Ketoglutarate: Many glucogenic amino acids, such as glutamine and glutamate, can be converted into α-ketoglutarate, which is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle. α-Ketoglutarate plays a crucial role in both energy production and amino acid metabolism.

questions.text: Methionine enter into TCA cycle at which point
Which of the following amino acid does not enter into TCA cycle at the level of acetyl CoA via pyruvate
All of the following enzymes use pyruvate as a substrate except
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Malic enzyme: Malic enzyme uses pyruvate as a substrate. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to malate by adding CO 2 . This reaction is important for the production of NADPH in cells and is part of the malate-aspartate shuttle.
  • • (B) Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) also uses pyruvate as a substrate. It catalyzes the reduction of pyruvate to lactate while oxidizing NADH to NAD + , a key reaction in anaerobic metabolism.
  • • (C) Alanine transaminase: Alanine transaminase (ALT) also uses pyruvate as a substrate. It catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from glutamate to pyruvate, producing alanine and α-ketoglutarate. This enzyme plays an important role in amino acid metabolism.

questions.text: Thiamin requirements is increase in excessive intake of which of the following molecules

options.label: C
options.text: Increase lactate in CSF is associated with good prognosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase lactate in CSF is associated with good prognosis
